data.key: Completion of Coosa Graphite Deposit Evaluation
data.value: End of 2028
Alabama Graphite is obligated to pay a net smelter return royalty of 2.00% for graphite production.
A further obligation includes a 0.50% net smelter return royalty, capped at $150,000, and payments of $100,000 for a bankable feasibility study completion and $150,000 post full permitting.
Good access via paved highways, some dirt and gravel logging roads.
First graphite production was in 1899; intermittent production in the area continued into the 1940s.
Graphite is hosted within Precambrian to Paleozoic rocks of the Higgins Ferry Group.
Grades generally one percent or less in some schists; exceed one percent in quartz-graphite schist.
Previous exploration included core drilling and airborne geophysical surveys. A near-surface deposit was defined.
The Company holds an exploration license and is applying for necessary permits for future development.

That part of a mineral resource for which quantity and grade or quality are estimated on the basis of adequate geological evidence and sampling. The level of geological certainty associated with an indicated mineral resource is sufficient to allow a qualified person to apply modifying factors in sufficient detail to support mine planning and evaluation of the economic viability of the deposit. Because an indicated mineral resource has a lower level of confidence than the level of confidence of a measured mineral resource, an indicated mineral resource may only be converted to a probable mineral reserve.

That part of a mineral resource for which quantity and grade or quality are estimated on the basis of limited geological evidence and sampling. The level of geological uncertainty associated with an inferred mineral resource is too high to apply relevant technical and economic factors likely to influence the prospects of economic extraction in a manner useful for evaluation of economic viability. Because an inferred mineral resource has the lowest level of geological confidence of all mineral resources, which prevents the application of the modifying factors in a manner useful for evaluation of economic viability, an inferred mineral resource may not be considered when assessing the economic viability of a mining project and may not be converted to a probable mineral reserve.

The Company values the natural flake graphite concentrate at the lower of cost or net realizable value.

Net realizable value represents the estimated future sales price of the product based on current and long-term graphite prices, less the estimated costs to complete production and bring the product to sale.
Write-downs of the natural flake graphite concentration to net realizable value are reported as a component of costs applicable to sales.

elements.title: Risks Related to Exploration and Mining Activities

data.value: Our property is in the exploration stage.
There is no assurance that we can establish the existence of any Mineral Reserve on the property in commercially exploitable quantities.
If we do not discover any Mineral Reserves in commercially exploitable quantity, our business could be adversely impacted.
We have established Mineral Resources at the Coosa Graphite Deposit but have not established any Mineral Reserves according to recognized reserve guidelines.
There is no guarantee that a deposit will also be a 'reserve' that meets the requirements of S-K 1300.
Both mineral exploration and development involve a high degree of risk.
The commercial viability depends on factors including deposit attributes, market prices, costs, political risks, labor availability, and governmental regulations.
Most exploration projects do not result in the discovery of commercially mineable deposits.
The Company discovered vanadium concentrations at the Coosa Graphite Deposit.
The extent of vanadium mineral reserves is unknown and may not be economically feasible for extraction.
Potential investors should be aware of the difficulties normally encountered by new mineral exploration ventures.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to the Coosa Graphite Deposit

data.value: The Company may not be able to obtain surface or access rights necessary for mining activities.
Enforcement of access rights can be costly and time-consuming, and the Company may need to negotiate access or purchase rights.
Exploration and development are risky and could result in environmental liabilities.
If liabilities exceed insurance, operations may be affected.
Few explored properties are developed into production, with various operational risks.
Title to the Coosa Graphite Deposit may have defects or be subject to claims.
Failure to make cash payments under lease agreements may result in loss of interests.

FORM 10-K SUMMARY
A preliminary technical and economic study of the economic potential of all or parts of mineralization to support the disclosure of mineral resources.

The initial assessment must be prepared by a qualified person and must include appropriate assessments of reasonably assumed technical and economic factors, together with any other relevant operational factors.
An initial assessment is required for disclosure of mineral resources but cannot be used as the basis for disclosure of mineral reserves.

The Company has never paid dividends and does not anticipate paying them in the foreseeable future.
The Company reviews and evaluates its long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the related carrying amounts may not be recoverable.

The Company considers events or changes in circumstances such as significant negative impacts in the market price of graphite, a significant adverse change in the extent or manner to use long-lived assets, and accumulation of costs over projected budgets.
Future cash flows are estimated based on quantities of recoverable minerals, expected commodity prices, production levels, and operating costs.
No impairment was recorded in 2022 or 2021.
Inventory consisted of raw material of natural flake graphite concentrate purchased from a non-related third party.
The Company values inventory at the lower of cost or net realizable value.

elements.title: Regulatory Compliance and Environmental Regulations for Graphite Operations

data.value: Graphite extraction and processing is regulated by federal and state governments.
Compliance with regulations has a material effect on the economics of operations and project development timing.
Primary costs relate to obtaining licenses and operating permits from federal and state agencies.
The regulatory process can make permitting difficult and timing unpredictable.
Required permits include air emissions, water discharge, storm water drainage.
The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit was received on January 31, 2022.
Air permit and State Indirect Discharge permit were obtained in June 2022 and August 2022, respectively.
Graphite mining requires various permits related to air, water, or environmental emissions.
Permits may be required under the Alabama Surface Mining Act of 1969 for stripping coal.
Groundwater withdrawals are managed through the Alabama Water Use Reporting Program.

elements.title: Regulatory Litigation Related to Mining Licenses

data.value: The Company faced the revocation of mining and exploration licenses for the Temrezli and Sefaatli projects in Turkey, leading to arbitration for compensation.
December 13, 2018
International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)
Request for Arbitration registered, Turkey's request to bifurcate denied, Counter-Memorial filed on September 14, 2020.
Awaiting a formal ruling on compensation and related issues.

elements.title: Legal Proceedings Dispute with Fabrice Taylor

data.value: Fabrice Taylor
Alabama Graphite Corp. and former officers and director
Defamation and slander
CAD$3.0 million
CAD$7.0 million
Not prosecuted, no schedule for resolution

Future operations on the Company’s properties are subject to federal and state regulations for the protection of the environment, including air and water quality. The Company evaluates the status of current environmental laws and their potential impact on current operating costs and accrual for future costs. The Company believes its operations are materially compliant with current, applicable environmental regulations.

At any given time, the Company may enter into negotiations to settle outstanding legal proceedings and any resulting accruals will be estimated based on the relevant facts and circumstances applicable at that time. We do not expect that such settlements will, individually or in the aggregate, have a material effect on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
